title: TV Pick of the Day: The Graham Norton Show, BBC1, October 9
text:
Comments (0) 
The Graham Norton Show (BBC1, 10.35pm) 
When new movie Suffragette opens at a cinema near you in the coming days, viewers may marvel at the acting prowess of Carey Mulligan and Meryl Streep, and rightly so. 
But without the right technical advisers, this story examining the struggle of the British women's suffrage movement in the late 19th and early 20th century could end up looking like a bad spoof. 
Obviously Graham Norton would struggle to attract ratings if he started interviewing advisers instead of Hollywood royalty, but chances are Ms Streep and Ms Mulligan will be the first to heap praise on the likes of Elizabeth Crawford. 
The book dealer on women's history had spent years researching the suffrage movement, and her ebook Kate Parry Frye - The Long Life of An Edwardian Actress and Suffragette is worthy of any Tinseltown movie. 
In 2009, Elizabeth had been told about Kate's diaries which were lying in a wet north London cellar. 
The diarist had died in 1959 and they wound up with people who had no connection with her. 
Elizabeth saw that these damp books were packed with ephemera and flyers about the women's suffrage movement and knew it was right up her street. 
"So as a dealer I bought them, but when I got them home and dried them all out and started reading, I just got gripped," she explains. 
Her book Campaigning for the Vote, examining Kate's suffrage years, was one of the many inspirations for the movie on which she worked. And with an all-star cast, including Helena Bonham Carter, Ben Whishaw and Brendan Gleeson, Suffragette (which opens on October 12) is already attracting Oscar buzz. 
It's scripted by Emmy winner Abi Morgan, who had something of a golden year in 2011. Aside from penning Streep's acclaimed Margaret Thatcher biopic The Iron Lady, she also wrote Mulligan's compelling sex addict drama Shame. 
Nicole Kidman is also no stranger to playing powerful women alongside Meryl Streep. 
Her turn as Virginia Woolf landed her an Oscar and a Bafta in 2003 for The Hours, and there's a good chance her performance as scientist Rosalind Franklin in West End hit Photograph 13 will also attract plaudits aplenty. 
Franklin, an English chemist, was one of the pioneering forces who helped discover the secrets of DNA and viruses. 
Nicole will be dropping into the studio to discuss that drama, and might also lift the lid on the other half dozen projects she's lined up for, including The Family Fang, Genius, and Secret in Their Eyes. 
Naturally Graham will be keeping the atmosphere as light as a souffle, so there's little chance of viewers learning too much about the suffrage movement or cracking the DNA code. 
This is Friday night telly after all, and a show which is more about making viral clips than talking about viruses. 
However, if there's time, we will get to experience another red chair moment as a member, or members, of the public recall some of their most embarrassing experiences before either walking free or abruptly showing their feet to the masses.
